natural problem:
The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$.
natural solution: Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\

&= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
&=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
and f :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "z = Complex (Re (-1/2)) (Im (sqrt 3 / 2))"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
shows  "f r1 = f r2 = f r3 = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
and f :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "z = Complex (Re (-1/2)) (Im (sqrt 3 / 2))"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
shows  "f r1 = f r2 = f r3 = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Let $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, where $z = -\frac{1}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, and $s1, s2,$ and $s3$ are defined as follows: 

$s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, 

$s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, 

$s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$.

Given that the sum of the real parts of $a, b,$ and $c$ equals $-26$, find the values of $r1, r2,$ and $r3$ such that $f(r1) = f(r2) = f(r3) = 0$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "z = Complex (-1 / 2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "z = Complex (-1 / 2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two complex functions $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, and three complex numbers $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$, where $z = -1/2 + i\sqrt{3}/2$, find the real part of the sum of coefficients $a$, $b$, and $c$ in $g(x)$, such that Re$(a + b + c) = -26$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
and f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "z = Complex (Re (-1/2)) (Im (sqrt 3 / 2))"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = x ^ 3 - 3 * x ^ 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = x ^ 3 + a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z ^ 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z ^ 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z ^ 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
and f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "z = Complex (Re (-1/2)) (Im (sqrt 3 / 2))"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = x ^ 3 - 3 * x ^ 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = x ^ 3 + a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z ^ 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z ^ 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z ^ 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $z = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i$, $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$, $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$. Find the real part of $a + b + c$, given that it equals -26.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "z = Complex (-1 / 2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h6 : "Re a + Re b + Re c = -26"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "z = Complex (-1 / 2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h6 : "Re a + Re b + Re c = -26"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two complex functions $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, where $a, b, c$ are complex numbers, and a complex number $z = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i$. Let $s1$, $s2$, and $s3$ be defined as $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$ respectively. If the real parts of $a$, $b$, and $c$ sum to $-26$, show that the real part of the sum of $a$, $b$, and $c$ is $-26$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c z :: complex
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "z = Complex (-1/2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
and h1 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h2 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h3 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h4 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h5 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "roots f = {r1, r2, r3}"
and h7 : "roots g = {s1, s2, s3}"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c z :: complex
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "z = Complex (-1/2) (sqrt 3 / 2)"
and h1 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h2 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h3 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h4 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h5 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "roots f = {r1, r2, r3}"
and h7 : "roots g = {s1, s2, s3}"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Given a complex number $z = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i$, and three roots $r1, r2, r3$ of a polynomial $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$, define three new roots $s1, s2, s3$ as $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$ and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$ of a new polynomial $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$. 

What is the real part of the sum of the coefficients $a + b + c$ of the polynomial $g$? The final answer is $-26$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "f r1 = 0"
and h3 : "f r2 = 0"
and h4 : "f r3 = 0"
and h5 : "g s1 = 0"
and h6 : "g s2 = 0"
and h7 : "g s3 = 0"
and h8 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h9 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h10 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h11 : "z = (-1 + \<i> * sqrt 3) / 2"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "f r1 = 0"
and h3 : "f r2 = 0"
and h4 : "f r3 = 0"
and h5 : "g s1 = 0"
and h6 : "g s2 = 0"
and h7 : "g s3 = 0"
and h8 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h9 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h10 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h11 : "z = (-1 + \<i> * sqrt 3) / 2"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Given two cubic functions, $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, where $f(x)$ has roots $r1, r2, r3$ and $g(x)$ has roots $s1, s2, s3$. The roots of $g(x)$ can be expressed as transformations of the roots of $f(x)$ using a complex number $z = \frac{-1 + i\sqrt{3}}{2}$ such that:
$s1 = r1 + r2*z + r3*z^2$,
$s2 = r1*z + r2*z^2 + r3$, and
$s3 = r1*z^2 + r2 + r3*z$.
Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients $a$, $b$, and $c$ of $g(x)$. The final answer is $-26$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "poly f r1 = 0"
and h2 : "poly f r2 = 0"
and h3 : "poly f r3 = 0"
and h4 : "let z = -1 / 2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h5 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h6 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h7 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h8 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h9 : "poly g s1 = 0"
and h10 : "poly g s2 = 0"
and h11 : "poly g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
fixes r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "poly f r1 = 0"
and h2 : "poly f r2 = 0"
and h3 : "poly f r3 = 0"
and h4 : "let z = -1 / 2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h5 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h6 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h7 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h8 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h9 : "poly g s1 = 0"
and h10 : "poly g s2 = 0"
and h11 : "poly g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Consider two cubic polynomials. The first polynomial, $f(x)$, is given by $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and has roots $r1$, $r2$, and $r3$. The second polynomial, $g(x)$, is given by $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$ and has roots $s1$, $s2$, and $s3$ which are obtained by transforming the roots of $f(x)$ via a complex number $z = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}i}{2}$. Specifically, $s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z^2$, $s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1 * z^2 + r2 + r3 * z$. 

The problem is to find the real part of the sum of the coefficients $a$, $b$, and $c$ of $g(x)$. The final answer is $-26$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x z :: complex and f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "z = -1/2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "roots g = {s1, s2, s3}"
shows  "Re (a + b + c + 1) = -26"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x z :: complex and f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "z = -1/2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h2 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h3 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h4 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h6 : "roots g = {s1, s2, s3}"
shows  "Re (a + b + c + 1) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider two polynomial functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$, where $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$. The roots of the polynomial $g(x)$ are given by $s1$, $s2$, and $s3$, which are defined by the complex number $z = -1/2 + i\sqrt{3}/2$ and the coefficients $r1$, $r2$, and $r3$ as follows: $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$. Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients $a$, $b$, $c$, and $1$ of the polynomial $g(x)$ such that it is equal to -26.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "z = (-1 + \<i> * sqrt 3) / 2"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h6 : "f r1 = f r2 = f r3 = 0"
and h7 : "g s1 = g s2 = g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h2 : "z = (-1 + \<i> * sqrt 3) / 2"
and h3 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h4 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h5 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h6 : "f r1 = f r2 = f r3 = 0"
and h7 : "g s1 = g s2 = g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Let $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are complex numbers. Suppose $r1$, $r2$, $r3$ are the roots of $f(x)$ and $s1$, $s2$, $s3$ are the roots of $g(x)$, where $s1 = r1 + r2z + r3z^2$, $s2 = r1z + r2z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1z^2 + r2 + r3z$ for some complex number $z = \frac{-1 + i\sqrt{3}}{2}$. What is the real part of $a + b + c$? The final answer is $-26$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "f r1 = 0"
and h2 : "f r2 = 0"
and h3 : "f r3 = 0"
and h4 : "z = -1 / 2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h5 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h6 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h7 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h8 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h9 : "g s1 = 0"
and h10 : "g s2 = 0"
and h11 : "g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^3-3x^2-4x+4$ has three real roots $r_1$, $r_2$, and $r_3$.  Let $g(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ be the polynomial which has roots $s_1$, $s_2$, and $s_3$, where
\begin{align*}
s_1 &= r_1+r_2z+r_3z^2, \\
s_2 &= r_1z+r_2z^2+r_3, \\
s_3 &= r_1z^2+r_2+r_3z,
\end{align*}and $z=\frac{-1+i\sqrt3}2$.  Find the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$. The final Answer is -26
 ### Proof
 Note that $z^2 + z + 1 = 0$ and $z^3 = 1.$  Also, note that $s_2 = zs_1$ and $s_3 = z^2 s_1.$ The sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is \begin{align} g(1) &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_2)(1 - s_3) \\ &= (1 - s_1)(1 - s_1 z)(1 - s_1 z^2) \\
 &= 1 - (1 + z + z^2) s_1 + (z + z^2 + z^3) s_1^2 - z^3 s_1^3 \\ &= 1 - s_1^3. \end{align}We have that \[s_1^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 + 3r_1^2 r_2 z + 3r_1^2 r_3 z^2 + 3r_2^2 r_3 z + 3r_2^2 r_1 z^2 + 3r_3^2 r_1 z + 3r_3^2 r_2 z^2 + 6r_1 r_2 r_3.\]Note that $r_1,$ $r_2,$ and $r_3$ are all real, and the real part of both $z$ and $z^2$ are $-\frac{1}{2},$ so the real part of $s_1^3$ is
 \begin{align} &r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 - \frac{3}{2} (r_1^2 r_2 + r_1 r_2^2 + r_1^2 r_3 + r_1 r_3^2 + r_2^2 r_3 + r_2 r_3^2) + 6r_1 r_2 r_3 \\ &= (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)^3 - \frac{9}{2} (r_1 + r_2 + r_3)(r_1 r_2 + r_1 r_3 + r_2 r_3) + \frac{27}{2} r_1 r_2 r_3 \\
 &=3^3 - \frac{9}{2} (3)(-4) + \frac{27}{2} (-4) = 27. \end{align}Hence, the real part of the sum of the coefficients of $g(x)$ is $1 - 27 = \boxed{-26}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and r1 r2 r3 s1 s2 s3 z a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 3 - 3 * x powr 2 - 4 * x + 4"
and h1 : "f r1 = 0"
and h2 : "f r2 = 0"
and h3 : "f r3 = 0"
and h4 : "z = -1 / 2 + \<i> * sqrt 3 / 2"
and h5 : "s1 = r1 + r2 * z + r3 * z powr 2"
and h6 : "s2 = r1 * z + r2 * z powr 2 + r3"
and h7 : "s3 = r1 * z powr 2 + r2 + r3 * z"
and h8 : "\<forall>x. g x = x powr 3 + a * x powr 2 + b * x + c"
and h9 : "g s1 = 0"
and h10 : "g s2 = 0"
and h11 : "g s3 = 0"
shows  "Re (a + b + c) = -26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two cubic functions $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 - 4x + 4$ and $g(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c$, and given three roots $r1$, $r2$, $r3$ of $f(x)$ such that $f(r1) = f(r2) = f(r3) = 0$. Let $z = -1/2 + i\sqrt{3}/2$ and define $s1 = r1 + r2*z + r3*z^2$, $s2 = r1*z + r2*z^2 + r3$, and $s3 = r1*z^2 + r2 + r3*z$. If $s1$, $s2$, and $s3$ are roots of $g(x)$, i.e., $g(s1) = g(s2) = g(s3) = 0$, find the real part of the sum of the coefficients $a$, $b$, and $c$ of $g(x)$. The final answer is $-26$.
